channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Italy releases Iranian man wanted by U.S. over drone attack that killed 3 soldiers
item.description: The release of Mohammad Abedini follows Iran's recent freeing of Italian journalist Cecilia Sala, sparking speculation that Sala may have been a bargaining chip.
item.content:encoded:
The release of Mohammad Abedini follows Iran's recent freeing of Italian journalist Cecilia Sala, sparking speculation that Sala may have been a bargaining chip.

(Image credit: Alessandra Tarantino)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman

item.title: On the way out: Transportation Sec. Buttigieg looks back on achievements, challenges
item.description:
From handling crises in the rail and airline industries to overseeing the distribution of billions of dollars in infrastructure funding, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg has taken on a lot over the last four years.

Now, his tenure is coming to an end.

Host Scott Detrow speaks with Buttigieg about what the Biden administration accomplished, what it didn't get done, and what he's taking away from an election where voters resoundingly called for something different.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org

Email us at considerthis@npr.org
item.content:encoded:
From handling crises in the rail and airline industries to overseeing the distribution of billions of dollars in infrastructure funding, Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg has taken on a lot over the last four years.

Now, his tenure is coming to an end.

Host Scott Detrow speaks with Buttigieg about what the Biden administration accomplished, what it didn't get done, and what he's taking away from an election where voters resoundingly called for something different.

(Image credit: Alex Wong)

item.title: Why Los Angeles, America's most fire-ready city, became overwhelmed by flames
item.description: In a city prone to large natural disasters, L.A. firefighters are widely considered to be among the best in the business at knocking down urban wildfires. But in the extreme conditions lately, experts say little can be done even to slow these modern fires.
item.content:encoded:
In a city prone to large natural disasters, L.A. firefighters are widely considered to be among the best in the business at knocking down urban wildfires. But in the extreme conditions lately, experts say little can be done even to slow these modern fires.

(Image credit: Eric Thayer)
item.dc:creator: Kirk Siegler

item.title: California governor says fires could prove the costliest disaster in U.S. history
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom told NBC's Meet The Press he believes the fires will be the nation's worst natural disaster "in terms of just the costs associated with it, in terms of the scale and scope."
item.content:encoded:
Gov. Gavin Newsom told NBC's Meet The Press he believes the fires will be the nation's worst natural disaster "in terms of just the costs associated with it, in terms of the scale and scope."

(Image credit: John Locher)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster

item.title: Southern California wildfires destroy or damage many houses of worship
item.description: Faith communities in Los Angeles are trying to protect their homes and houses of worship from deadly wildfires. They are also trying to provide spiritual support for their traumatized congregations.
item.content:encoded:
Faith communities in Los Angeles are trying to protect their homes and houses of worship from deadly wildfires. They are also trying to provide spiritual support for their traumatized congregations.

(Image credit: Chris Pizzello)
item.dc:creator: Jason DeRose

item.title: FEMA's administrator says more than 24,000 in LA have applied for assistance
item.description: "People have lost everything," says FEMA administrator Deanne Criswell. More than 24,000 have already applied for assistance from FEMA, but Criswell says that number is certain to rise.
item.content:encoded:
"People have lost everything," says FEMA administrator Deanne Criswell. More than 24,000 have already applied for assistance from FEMA, but Criswell says that number is certain to rise.

(Image credit: Jae C. Hong)
item.dc:creator: Ayesha Rascoe

item.title: Kate Bowler wants to have more 'uncounted, completely-wasted, doesn't-matter time'
item.description: On Wild Card this week, Kate Bowler opens up about how she wants to waste her time, her feelings about God and how she talks about death with her child.
item.content:encoded:
On Wild Card this week, Kate Bowler opens up about how she wants to waste her time, her feelings about God and how she talks about death with her child.

(Image credit: Kate Bowler)
item.dc:creator: Rachel Martin

item.title: Kangaroo species went extinct in the Pleistocene. Research hops in with a possible explanation.
item.description: In a mass extinction event some 40,000 years ago, Australia lost 90% of its large species, including nearly two dozen kinds of kangaroos. Two theories suggest why.
item.content:encoded:
In a mass extinction event some 40,000 years ago, Australia lost 90% of its large species, including nearly two dozen kinds of kangaroos. Two theories suggest why.

(Image credit: Traci Klarenbeek)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: 7 global buzzwords for 2025: From 'techquity' to 'climate displacement' to 'belonging'
item.description: What words will be buzzing about in the global health and development hive in the year ahead? Our experts have nominations for your consideration.
item.content:encoded: What words will be buzzing about in the global health and development hive in the year ahead? Our experts have nominations for your consideration.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Exit interview: DOT Sec. Buttigieg on infrastructure act and the road ahead
item.description: In an exit interview with All Things Considered, DOT Secretary Pete Buttigieg reflects on the Biden administration's infrastructure act and why it didn't resonate with some voters.
item.content:encoded:
In an exit interview with All Things Considered, DOT Secretary Pete Buttigieg reflects on the Biden administration's infrastructure act and why it didn't resonate with some voters.

(Image credit: Shuran Huang)
item.dc:creator: Scott Detrow
